attributes.title: Lexical Tone as a Linguistic Cue During Bilingual Cross-situational Word Learning

q1.value: Lexical Tone as a Linguistic Cue During Bilingual Cross-situational Word Learning

q3.value:
Adults learn correct 1:1 word-referent mapping by calculating co-occurrences between words and their referent across multiple scenes (Cross-situational statistical learning, CSSL; Yu & Smith, 2007). Also, adults learn 2:1 word-referent mapping, where two words co-occur with the same referent (Bilingual CSSL; Benitez et al., 2016; Poepsel & Weiss, 2016; Chan & Monaghan, 2019). 
Bilinguals encounter translation equivalents daily, where the two words mapped onto the same object are linguistically distinctive. However, to present, bilingual CSSL studies have not fully investigated the linguistic difference between the two words mapped on to the same referent. Therefore, this study intends to answer two questions: a. Does adult bilingual CSSL differ when the two words mapped onto the same object are differentiated by a linguistic cue than when they are not? and b. How does language experience interact with the presence of a linguistic cue during bilingual CSSL?
To answer these questions, adults will be presented with a bilingual CSSL task where word-object pairings are ambiguous in each individual trial, but learnable across trials by tracking word-object co-occurrences. Specifically, each object will co-occur most often with two words. Two conditions will manipulate if the two words sharing a referent are differentiated. In the Cued Condition, each of two words mapped onto the same object are distinctive in pitch contours—one without pitch variation (flat tone), the other with pitch contour either of Tone2-Tone4 or Tone4-Tone2 in Mandarin tones. In the Uncued Condition, each word in a word pair is not distinctive from the other in pitch contour—both words will be presented without pitch variation. Two groups differentiated in language-specific experiences will be recruited—English speakers, who are unfamiliar with tonal variation at the syllabic level, and Mandarin-English speakers, who are familiar with tonal variation. In order to control the difference between the two selected groups, participants’ spatial working memory (Symmetry Span Task) and phonological working memory (L1 Digit Span task) will be collected as covariates for data analysis. To measure language and music background (both features that are likely to affect word learning and tonal perception), participants will also complete a language background questionnaire and a music questionnaire.

q4.value: If a linguistic cue differentiating the two words sharing a referent facilitates learning in bilingual CSSL, then adults should perform better on both words of a referent in the Cued condition than in the Uncued condition. If, however, the linguistic cue hinders learning, then adults should perform better in the Cued condition than in the Uncued condition. It is also possible that a linguistic cue does not affect learning, in which case we should see no difference between the Cued and Uncued conditions. Finally, language experience may interact with the effects of the linguistic cue. Specifically, if the linguistic cue has a general effect on learning, then both tonal (Mandarin-English speakers) and non-tonal speakers (English speakers) will perform equally on the Cued condition compared to the Uncued condition. If however, language-specific experience of tone information affects the ability to use the linguistic cue, then Mandarin-English speakers should perform differently than English speakers.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: Adults will not know which condition they are assigned to. Experimenters are always trained to not influence participants’ performance as best as possible, and because the study is run entirely on a computer, it is difficult for the experimenter to influence participants’ performance.

question.value:
All adults will complete both conditions of the word learning task, a spatial memory task, a phonological memory task, and a language and musical background questionnaire in this order.
 
1. Word learning tasks. In the word learning task, each participant will complete two versions of the task: the Cued condition and the Uncued condition (order will be counterbalanced across participants). For each condition, participants will be presented with 16 word-object pairings to learn, with each of 8 objects linked with two words (W1 and W2). In the Cued Condition, W1 and W2 are linguistically different; W1 will contain Mandarin lexical tone information either in Tone2-Tone4 pattern (T2-T4), or Tone4-Tone2 pattern (T4-T2) (e.g. gùbí, T4-T2); W2 will have no information of lexical tone (e.g. batu, non-tone). In the Uncued Condition, W1 and W2 will be equivalent in having no information of lexical tone (e.g. migu and gadi, non-tone). Both words for an object will always be presented across trials (never on the same trial) but intermixed during training. For each condition, participants will complete a training followed by immediate testing. 
During training, adults will be presented auditorily with two words and see two objects at a time on a computer screen; the order of the words and the location of the objects are randomized so that word-object pairings will be ambiguous within a trial. Across trials, however, each word will occur 6 times and most often with its referent object (each object will occur 12 times, 6 times with one word and 6 times with the other). After training, adults will be tested on their learning of the word-referent pairings. On each test trial, a word will be auditorily be presented with its target object and 3 distractor objects (distractor objects are other objects presented during training). Adults will be instructed to select the target object using the mouse. Each word will be tested once for a total of 16 test trials. The word learning tasks will last around 20 minutes.

2. Spatial memory task. After the word learning tasks, participants will complete an adaptive symmetry span task to measure spatial working memory skills. In the task, adults will be asked to recall the location and sequence of a number of flashing squares on the computer screen, at the same time making an irrelevant judgement about whether a picture is symmetric or not. The symmetry span task will last around 10 minutes.

3. Phonological memory task. Adults will be instructed to complete a digit span task in their native language (either English or Mandrain) to measure phonological working memory skills. Participants will hear a sequence of auditory numbers in their first language at the rate of one digit per second. Later on, they will be asked to recall the sequence of the heard digits in order. The L1 digit span task will last around 12 minutes.

4. Questionnaires. Last, a language background questionnaire will be distributed to record participants’ language use, e.g. experiences with other languages, L2 age of acquisition and L2 fluency. A music background questionnaire will ask questions about musical training experience, which is shown to mutually influence lexical tonal knowledge. Questionnaire filling may last around 10 minutes.

In all, this study will be a 2×2×2 design, with a between-subjects factor of Language Group (non-tonal speakers v.s. tonal speakers), a within-subjects factor of Condition (Cued Condition v.s. Uncued Condition), and a within-subjects factor of Word (W1 v.s. W2). The entire procedure will last approximately 60 minutes. Accuracy and reaction time will be recorded in all tasks (not in questionnaires).

q9.value: Each participant will go through two conditions of the word learning task, with order counterbalanced across participants. Each condition of training is randomly assigned according to four different variables, condition (Cued (Tone 2-4 or Tone4-2) or Uncued), list (one of the 45 randomized training and testing lists differing in word-object parings and order of trials), object set (set1 and set2 differing in the 8 objects used), and word set (set1 and set2 differing in the 16 words used).

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: We will not use existing data for this study.

question.value:
1.	Subject Pool
A total number of 90 participants will be recruited from Arizona State University (ASU) (N=45 for English monolinguals, N=45 for Chinese-English bilinguals). Sample size was determined according to the sample size and significance level of experiment 3 in Benitez, Yurovsky, & Smith (2016), and a statistical website for generating sample size (https://designingexperiments.shinyapps.io/BUCSS_ss_power_spa/). We will monitor the data collection process to ensure we achieve the target sample size when considering withdrawn cases, e.g. participants' quitting or participants not fitting our language groups.
All participants will be ASU college students. We will have two channels to recruit participants. One is from ASU’s Introduction to Psychology student subject pool in which students register to participate in studies for course credit; the other is from on-campus flyers with monetary incentive for participation. 
2.	Venue for Data Collection
All tasks will be run in an adult-testing room in General Psychology Building in Arizona State University. Two participants can be tested at the same time with two computers.
3.	Procedures
All participants will be given a Consent Form to know that their participation is voluntary and can withdraw anytime during the experiment. They will also be briefly informed of the study.
Individual participants’ data will be excluded if participants do not complete both conditions of the word learning task, and/or if English monolinguals report they do not belong to monolingual group.

q13.value: Total number of 90 participants will be recruited from Arizona State University (ASU) (N=45 for English monolinguals, N=45 for Chinese-English bilinguals).

q14.value: Sample size (N=90 in total, N=45 for English monolingual and Chinese-English bilingual groups) was determined according to the sample size and significance level of experiment 3 in Benitez et al’s study (2016), and a statistical website for generating sample size (https://designingexperiments.shinyapps.io/BUCSS_ss_power_spa/).

q15.value: Data collection will stop when we collect the desired number of participants.

question.value: Two main variables of interest are manipulated. Within-subjects we manipulate whether words that share an object in the bilingual CSSL task are differentiated by a linstuistic cue (Cued vs. Uncued). The linguistic cue is lexical tone information. In the Cued Condition, each of two words linked with the same object (W1 and W2) are linguistically different; W1 will be embedded with Mandarin lexical tone either in Tone2-Tone4 pattern (T2-T4), or Tone4-Tone2 pattern(T4-T2), e.g. gùbí (T4-T2); W2 will have no information of lexical tone, e.g. batu (non-tone). In the Uncued Condition, W1 and W2 will be equivalent in having no information of lexical tone, e.g. “migu” and “gadi”. Between-subjects we manipulate the language experience of the learners, to be either non-tonal experience (English monolingual speakers) or tonal experience (Mandarin-English bilingual speakers).

Main dependent variable:
1. Word learning task: The dependent variable will be participants’ mean accuracy scores for the two conditions (Cued and Uncued) and each word for a given object (W1 and W2). On each test trial (after training), a word will be presented with its target object and 3 distractor objects. Adults will be asked to select the object that is being named. Each word will be tested once for a total of 16 test trials. Accuracy will be measured as the mean accuracy for W1 and W2. The chance performance will be 0.25 (1 out of 4). 
Other dependent variables as co-variants:
2. Spatial working memory: participants’ mean accuracy on the symmetry span task.
3. Phonological working memory: participants’ mean accuracy on L1 digit span task (accumulated recalled digits).
4. Musical training experience: musical training experience based on whether participants were formally trained or not formally trained in music.

Confirmatory Data Analysis

To test whether adults are successful at learning, we will compare mean accuracy scores for each participant for each word (W1 and W2) for each condition ( Uncued Condition and Cued Condition) with 0.25 (chance performance) using one-sample t-tests.

To examine the effects of the linguistic cue, the effects of language experience, and the interaction between the two, we will conduct a mixed effects ANCOVA that will include the within-subjects factors of Word type (W1 vs. W2) and Condition (Cued vs. Uncued) and the between-subject factor of language group (English monolingual group vs. Mandarin-English bilingual group). Spatial working memory scores, phonological working memory scores, and musical training experience will be included as covariates.
Follow up analyses examining pairwise comparisons will be conducted to interpret any significant interactions found. P-values for these analyses will be corrected according to the Holm-Bonferroni method.

q21.value: We will use p value of 0.05 as criteria for determining if the results from the t-tests, ANCOVA, and pair-wise follow up comparisons suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypotheses were correct.

q22.value: Participants who do not complete both conditions of the word learning task will be excluded. English monolinguals who self-report not belong to monolinguals will be excluded.

q23.value: If a participant completes both conditions of the word learning task but does not complete one or more of the additional tasks, their performance on that specific task(s) will be excluded.

q24.value:
1.	If the difference between Cued and Uncued condition is significant, a multiple regression analysis will be run. In the regression model, criterion will be the different score between Cued and Uncued condition; predictors will be groups, spatial working memory score, phonological working memory score, music training.
2.	To explore the role of multiple measures (working memory skills as well as musical background) on word learning performance, a multiple linear regression analysis will be conducted to analyze the relationship between predictors (spatial working memory, phonological working memory, musical training experience) and word learning performance.
3.	In order to test the effect of bilingualism (bilinguals with different degree of L2 exposure), we will further analyze the Chinese-English bilingual group according to their L2 age of acquisition and L2 length of exposure. Using multiple regression analysis, we will set L2 age of acquisition and L2 length of exposure as predictors and word learning performance as the outcome.

registration_responses.q1: Lexical Tone as a Linguistic Cue During Bilingual Cross-situational Word Learning
registration_responses.q3:
Adults learn correct 1:1 word-referent mapping by calculating co-occurrences between words and their referent across multiple scenes (Cross-situational statistical learning, CSSL; Yu & Smith, 2007). Also, adults learn 2:1 word-referent mapping, where two words co-occur with the same referent (Bilingual CSSL; Benitez et al., 2016; Poepsel & Weiss, 2016; Chan & Monaghan, 2019). 
Bilinguals encounter translation equivalents daily, where the two words mapped onto the same object are linguistically distinctive. However, to present, bilingual CSSL studies have not fully investigated the linguistic difference between the two words mapped on to the same referent. Therefore, this study intends to answer two questions: a. Does adult bilingual CSSL differ when the two words mapped onto the same object are differentiated by a linguistic cue than when they are not? and b. How does language experience interact with the presence of a linguistic cue during bilingual CSSL?
To answer these questions, adults will be presented with a bilingual CSSL task where word-object pairings are ambiguous in each individual trial, but learnable across trials by tracking word-object co-occurrences. Specifically, each object will co-occur most often with two words. Two conditions will manipulate if the two words sharing a referent are differentiated. In the Cued Condition, each of two words mapped onto the same object are distinctive in pitch contours—one without pitch variation (flat tone), the other with pitch contour either of Tone2-Tone4 or Tone4-Tone2 in Mandarin tones. In the Uncued Condition, each word in a word pair is not distinctive from the other in pitch contour—both words will be presented without pitch variation. Two groups differentiated in language-specific experiences will be recruited—English speakers, who are unfamiliar with tonal variation at the syllabic level, and Mandarin-English speakers, who are familiar with tonal variation. In order to control the difference between the two selected groups, participants’ spatial working memory (Symmetry Span Task) and phonological working memory (L1 Digit Span task) will be collected as covariates for data analysis. To measure language and music background (both features that are likely to affect word learning and tonal perception), participants will also complete a language background questionnaire and a music questionnaire.

If, however, the linguistic cue hinders learning, then adults should perform better in the Cued condition than in the Uncued condition. It is also possible that a linguistic cue does not affect learning, in which case we should see no difference between the Cued and Uncued conditions. Finally, language experience may interact with the effects of the linguistic cue. Specifically, if the linguistic cue has a general effect on learning, then both tonal (Mandarin-English speakers) and non-tonal speakers (English speakers) will perform equally on the Cued condition compared to the Uncued condition. If however, language-specific experience of tone information affects the ability to use the linguistic cue, then Mandarin-English speakers should perform differently than English speakers.

attributes.title: Data extracted from the Implications for Research sections of reviews from two Cochrane Review Groups
attributes.description: Examination of the Implications for Research in reviews published by the Cochrane Schizophrenia and Multiple Sclerosis Review Groups

summary.value: Data on how to improve future trials in Schizophrenia and multiple sclerosis extracted from the 'Implications for research' sections of systematic reviews with citation dates between 2009 and mid-2019 by the Cochrane Schizophrenia Review Group (https://schizophrenia.cochrane.org) and the Cochrane Multiple Sclerosis and Rare Diseases of the CNS Review Group (https://msrdcns.cochrane.org).

q1.value: An investigation of the relationship between the stigmatisation of individuals with mental health conditions and overgeneralized disease avoidance.

q3.value: Both the avoidance of individuals with cues of infection and the stigmatization of individuals who are deemed to appear ‘atypical’ (e.g. obese individuals or individuals with facial lesions) are hypothesised to reflect a common underlying process of infectious disease avoidance. The current study aims to investigate the relationship between the stigmatisation of individuals with mental health conditions and overgeneralized disease avoidance, as measured by disgust sensitivity. The relationships between subscales of the Three Domain Disgust Scale (TDDS; Tyber, 2009) and the stigmatization of individuals with one of four mental health conditions (schizophrenia, depression, trichotillomania and anorexia nervosa) as measured through the AQ-27 (Corrigan, 2012), was investigated in a sample of 292 participants. It is hypothesised that scores on the pathogen disgust subscale of the Three Domain Disgust Scale will positively correlate with the stigmatization of all four mental health conditions.

q4.value: It is hypothesised that scores on the pathogen disgust subscale of the Three Domain Disgust Scale will positively correlate with the stigmatization of all four mental health conditions.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Between subjects design with 2 factors. Each participant completed a 27-item Attribution Questionnaire (AQ-27; Corrigan, 2008) from Corrigan’s toolkit for evaluating programs meant to erase the stigma of mental illness, followed by the Three Domain Disgust Scale (TDDS; Tybur et al., 2009).

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Data has been collected using GDPR compliant software.

question.value: Participants were recruited through social media. Participants must be aged 18 or over.

q14.value: Due to this being a dissertation, there is a constraint on how many participants can be recruited.

q15.value: We will stop collecting data after 300 participants

question.value: We will measure the scores of each participant on the AQ-27 for each vignette/ mental health condition. We will measure the scores of each participant on the TDDS.
We will used a linear mixed effects model and a simple linear model

q21.value: We will z scores participants scores prior to analysis

q22.value: NA scores will be removed from data

q23.value: NA scores will be removed from data

registration_responses.q1: An investigation of the relationship between the stigmatisation of individuals with mental health conditions and overgeneralized disease avoidance.
registration_responses.q3: Both the avoidance of individuals with cues of infection and the stigmatization of individuals who are deemed to appear ‘atypical’ (e.g. obese individuals or individuals with facial lesions) are hypothesised to reflect a common underlying process of infectious disease avoidance. The current study aims to investigate the relationship between the stigmatisation of individuals with mental health conditions and overgeneralized disease avoidance, as measured by disgust sensitivity. The relationships between subscales of the Three Domain Disgust Scale (TDDS; Tyber, 2009) and the stigmatization of individuals with one of four mental health conditions (schizophrenia, depression, trichotillomania and anorexia nervosa) as measured through the AQ-27 (Corrigan, 2012), was investigated in a sample of 292 participants. It is hypothesised that scores on the pathogen disgust subscale of the Three Domain Disgust Scale will positively correlate with the stigmatization of all four mental health conditions.
registration_responses.q4: It is hypothesised that scores on the pathogen disgust subscale of the Three Domain Disgust Scale will positively correlate with the stigmatization of all four mental health conditions.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

attributes.title: Do voters disbelieve uncongenial political facts to regulate their emotions?

q1.value: Do voters disbelieve uncongenial political facts to regulate their emotions?

q3.value:
The research question of this study is whether prior attitude effect in the evaluation of political information is an emotion regulation process. Prior attitude effect refers to a tendency to assess new information as disproportionately strong if it supports pre-existing beliefs (Druckman & McGrath, 2019; Lodge & Taber, 2013; Taber & Lodge, 2006). This corresponds, I argue, to evaluating information as disproportionately weak, if it challenges pre-existing beliefs.  
I investigate this in the context of perceptions of facts related to immigration politics in Denmark. Prior attitude effect is operationalized through belief in facts that are uncongenial to respondent’s immigration attitudes. High belief in uncongenial facts is taken as a sign of low prior attitude effect, and low belief in uncongenial political facts is taken as a sign of high degrees of prior attitude effect.  
The study’s theoretical outset is to test whether prior attitude effect is an instance of the emotion regulation strategy of cognitive change, which differs from the emotion regulation strategy of emotional acceptance. The expectations from this outset to be tested are (1) that individuals prone to using emotional acceptance as an emotion regulation strategy display less prior attitude effect than others, (2) that individuals prone to using cognitive change as an emotion regulation strategy display more prior attitude effect than others, and (3) that promoting use of emotional acceptance as an emotion regulation strategy reduces prior attitude effect in the evaluation of political information.

q4.value:
H1: Individual differences in emotional acceptance positively predict belief in uncongenial facts related to immigration politics, such that individuals high in emotional acceptance are more likely to believe uncongenial facts than others.  

H2: Individual differences in cognitive change negatively predict belief in uncongenial facts related to immigration politics, such that individuals high in cognitive change are less likely to believe uncongenial facts than others. 

H3: Promoting use of emotional acceptance as an emotion regulation strategy increases belief in uncongenial facts related to immigration politics.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: There is no personnel who interacts directly with the study subjects, as this is an online survey. Subjects are not aware that they are taking part in a survey experiment.

question.value:
The study begins with a cross-sectional part. Here the dependent variable is belief in two uncongenial facts related to immigration politics. For right-leaning respondents this corresponds to belief in two left-leaning facts, and for left-leaning respondents it corresponds to belief in right-leaning facts. I regress belief in uncongenial facts on individual difference measures of emotional acceptance and cognitive change, while controlling for sociodemographic covariates (age, gender, education and income), political sophistication and attitude strength. All variables included in the cross-sectional part of the study are measured before the experimental part of the study begins.  

In the experimental part of the study, respondents are randomly assigned to an emotional acceptance promoting task (the treatment condition) or a mind wandering task (the control condition). They then evaluate two new uncongenial facts related to immigration politics. The mean difference between the two groups in belief in these two uncongenial facts is the estimated causal effect of the experimental manipulation of emotional acceptance.

q9.value: I use the randomization feature in Qualtrics, the platform on which the study is hosted, to randomly assign respondents to the treatment or the control condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
I will recruit 1280 respondents from Dynata’s online panel in Denmark. Subjects will receive a gift-card code for their participation. Dynata uses a stratified recruitment strategy so as to ensure national representativity in terms of age, gender, education and region of residence. Only Danish citizens over the age of 18 will be permitted to participate in the study. Data collection is estimated to start on March 5th, 2020, and end around March 15th 2020. The survey was programmed in Qualtrics and will be run on Qualtrics.
I use an attention check in the beginning of the survey, and respondents who fail it, are weeded out of the survey. I also weed out respondents who do not listen to the entirety of the audio files used as experimental treatment and placebo, and respondents who spend less than 400 seconds on the entire survey. Responses that are weeded out in this way do not count toward the 1280 responses I will collect.

q14.value: I conducted a power analysis assuming the variance and average levels of belief in uncongenial factual statements would be the same as in a previous study. With a power level of 0.8, an alpha level of 0.05, and using a two-sided test, 1280 respondents should enable detecting a 6-percentagepoints treatment effect. Considering resource constraints, I deemed this acceptable.

q15.value: Data collection will not be terminated until the 1280 complete responses have been collected.

question.value: see the attached file
see the attached file
see the attached file
see the attached do file, which specifies the statistical models used to investigate the three hypotheses.

q20.value: To facilitate ease of interpretation, I will rescale all continuous variables used in the analyses (except age) to range from 0-1.

q21.value: In all analyses, I will use an alpha value of 0.05 and report two-sided p-values.

q22.value: I exclude all observations that did not finish the survey for example because of failing the attention check. Otherwise, I will not exclude any observations, except in the case of missing data.

q23.value: Respondents with missing data on one or more variables included in a regression will be excluded from the analysis. Considerations related to index construction, when there is missing data on one or more items, are discussed under the indices paragraph above.

This corresponds, I argue, to evaluating information as disproportionately weak, if it challenges pre-existing beliefs.  
I investigate this in the context of perceptions of facts related to immigration politics in Denmark. Prior attitude effect is operationalized through belief in facts that are uncongenial to respondent’s immigration attitudes. High belief in uncongenial facts is taken as a sign of low prior attitude effect, and low belief in uncongenial political facts is taken as a sign of high degrees of prior attitude effect.  
The study’s theoretical outset is to test whether prior attitude effect is an instance of the emotion regulation strategy of cognitive change, which differs from the emotion regulation strategy of emotional acceptance. The expectations from this outset to be tested are (1) that individuals prone to using emotional acceptance as an emotion regulation strategy display less prior attitude effect than others, (2) that individuals prone to using cognitive change as an emotion regulation strategy display more prior attitude effect than others, and (3) that promoting use of emotional acceptance as an emotion regulation strategy reduces prior attitude effect in the evaluation of political information.

comments.value:
General Information

This is a replication project being completed by an undergraduate Experimental Psychology course at Yeshiva University. A total of 18 undergraduate students and 3 graduate student instructors are contributing to the project, in addition to the PI (Lisa Chalik).

Abstract (from De Neys et al.)

Influential work on human thinking suggests that our judgment is often biased because we minimize cognitive effort and intuitively substitute hard questions by easier ones. A key question is whether or not people realize that they are doing this and notice their mistake. Here, we test this claim with one of the most publicized examples of the substitution bias, the bat-and-ball problem. We designed an isomorphic control version in which reasoners experience no intuitive pull to substitute. Results show that people are less confident in their substituted, erroneous bat-and-ball answer than in their answer on the control version that does not give rise to the substitution. Contrary to popular belief, this basic finding indicates that biased reasoners are not completely oblivious to the substitution and sense that their answer is questionable. This calls into question the characterization of the human reasoner as a happy fool who blindly answers erroneous questions without realizing it.

Planned Methods

This will be an exact replication of the original study. Participants will complete the replication online, through Qualtrics. We will collect a minimum N of 100 participants. These participants will be recruited through word-of-mouth, and will likely consist mostly of friends and family of the students conducting the project.

For exploratory purposes, we have also added some demographic questions at the end of the procedure.

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

We designed an isomorphic control version in which reasoners experience no intuitive pull to substitute. Results show that people are less confident in their substituted, erroneous bat-and-ball answer than in their answer on the control version that does not give rise to the substitution. Contrary to popular belief, this basic finding indicates that biased reasoners are not completely oblivious to the substitution and sense that their answer is questionable. These participants will be recruited through word-of-mouth, and will likely consist mostly of friends and family of the students conducting the project.

For exploratory purposes, we have also added some demographic questions at the end of the procedure.

Planned Methods

This will be an exact replication of the original study. Participants will complete the replication online, through Qualtrics. We will collect a minimum N of 100 participants. These participants will be recruited through word-of-mouth, and will likely consist mostly of friends and family of the students conducting the project.

For exploratory purposes, we have also added some demographic questions at the end of the procedure.

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

registration_responses.comments:
General Information

This is a replication project being completed by an undergraduate Experimental Psychology course at Yeshiva University. A total of 18 undergraduate students and 3 graduate student instructors are contributing to the project, in addition to the PI (Lisa Chalik).

Abstract (from De Neys et al.)

Influential work on human thinking suggests that our judgment is often biased because we minimize cognitive effort and intuitively substitute hard questions by easier ones. A key question is whether or not people realize that they are doing this and notice their mistake. Here, we test this claim with one of the most publicized examples of the substitution bias, the bat-and-ball problem. We designed an isomorphic control version in which reasoners experience no intuitive pull to substitute. Results show that people are less confident in their substituted, erroneous bat-and-ball answer than in their answer on the control version that does not give rise to the substitution. Contrary to popular belief, this basic finding indicates that biased reasoners are not completely oblivious to the substitution and sense that their answer is questionable. This calls into question the characterization of the human reasoner as a happy fool who blindly answers erroneous questions without realizing it.

Planned Methods

This will be an exact replication of the original study. Participants will complete the replication online, through Qualtrics. We will collect a minimum N of 100 participants. These participants will be recruited through word-of-mouth, and will likely consist mostly of friends and family of the students conducting the project.

For exploratory purposes, we have also added some demographic questions at the end of the procedure.
registration_responses.datacompletion: No, data collection has not begun
